climbs.name: Layaway Plan
climbs.fa: John Bachar, John Yablonski, and Mike Lechlinski, Dec. 1979

content.description: This is a steep and sustained fingertip lieback, requiring interesting footwork.
content.protection: It's a toprope problem, so you just need gear for the anchor on top.
content.location: This is on the back (southwest face) of Hemmingway Buttress.  It is an obvious fingertip lieback problem.

content.description: An interesting route on the lonely West face of Hemingway Buttress.  Start on scruffy rock, picking one of two branches of an inverted V crack.  Continue up the face clipping bolts until moving left to a nice seam.  From there trend left and up to the anchor.
content.protection: Pro to 2 inches, 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor (70' rap).
content.location:
The West face of Hemingway may be best seen/approached from the down climb of Freeway Wall.  You can also approach around the left side of the east face, circling around to the back of the formation.

This route is just left of American Express, and is the only bolt line on the buttress.  The picture on Pg. 326 in Joshua Tree West is slightly off, it takes the right crack of the V, while the left seems nicer.  The bolt line is also too far left in the picture.

Listed as 5.11d in the JTW, the path of least resistance seems more like 5.11-.

climbs.name: American Express
climbs.fa: John Yablonski and Mike Lechlinski, Dec. 1979

content.description: The crux is in the first 15 feet, but it's fairly sustained crack climbing the whole way.  If it's too cold on the northeast face of the formation, walk around here for a nice route in the sun.
content.location: This is the full length, slightly left-slanting crack to the left of Layaway Plan.
